FacilityName: U.S. Army Garrison Aberdeen Proving Ground

_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

This updated RMP covers the storage and use of chlorine at the Aberdeen Proving Ground (APG) water treatment plant (WTP) and wastewater treatment plant (WWTP), and the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia as an  refrigerant at the Climatic Firing Facility (CFF).

Facility Background:

The APG located approximately 30 miles north of Baltimore, Maryland and 50 miles south of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.  It occupies more than 72,500 acres in Harford County, Maryland.  44,000 of those acres are either wetlands, or under water, including portions of the Bush and Gunpowder River and the Chesapeake Bay.  The APG comprises two areas, the Aberdeen Proving Ground Aberdeen Area (APG-AA) and the Aberdeen Proving Ground Edgewood Area (APG-EA), which are 15 miles apart by land.  The APG is home to more than fifty tenants and numerous satellite activities.  Among the major tenants are the U.S. Army Test and Evaluation Command (ATEC); U.S. Army Ordnance Center and School (OC&S); U.S. Army Aberdeen Test Center (ATC); U.S. Army Research Development Engineering Command (RDECOM) which includes the U.S. Army Research Laboratory; U.S. Army Environmental Center (AEC); U.S. Army Center for Health Promotion and Preventive Medicine (USACHPPM); and the U.S. Army Medical Research Institute of Chemical Defense (MRICD).

Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

The APG is committed to being a safe neighbor and employer.  Prevention of accidents, employee safety and emergency response are all operations which have command support and visibility.  The APG follows applicable regulations, requirements and policies designed to provide a safe work environment.  

Regulated substances

Chlorine and anhydrous ammonia are currently the only chemicals for which APG is required to develop and implement a Risk Management Program.  Chlorine is used and stored at APG's WTP and WWTP, and is present over the threshold quantity of 2,000 pounds.   The anhydrous ammonia is utilized as a refr

igerant in an industrial refrigeration system for the CFF. The refrigerant charge exceeds the 10,000 lb threshold quantity. As a refrigerant it is not consumed but recycled through the closed system. 

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific prevention steps:

The APG has a Process Safety Management (PSM) Plan and an Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP).  APG's PSM Plan addresses safety in the workplace by identifying related work processes and assuring all safety measures required are followed.   The ICP describes additional procedures and regulations followed by various APG offices in preparation for response to a hazardous materials incident.  The ICP is included in this document by reference.  The following is a list of specific standards followed:

29 CFR 1910.119  Process safety management of highly hazardous chemicals.
29 CFR 1910.120    Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response
29 CFR 1910.38    Employee Emergency and Fire Protection Plans

40 CFR 110    Discharge of Oil
40 CFR 116    Hazardous Substances, Designation of
40 CFR 117    Hazardous Substances, Reportable Quantities
40 CFR 300    National Oil and Hazardous Substance Pollution Contingency Plan

PL 92-500    Federal Water Pollution Control Act, as amended

NFPA 471    Recommended Practice for Responding to Hazardous Material Incidents
NFPA 472    Professional Competence of Responders to Hazardous Material Incidents

EO 12088    Federal Compliance with Pollution Standards

DODD 5030.41    Oil and Hazardous Substance Pollution Prevention and Contingency Program
DODD 6050.8    Storage and Disposal of Non-DOD Owned Hazardous or Toxic Materials on DOD Installations

AR 200-1    Environmental Protection and Enhancement
AR 385-40    Accident Reporting and Records
AR 420-90    Fire Protection
AR 500-60    Disaster Relief

Five Year Accident History:

There have been no documented accidental off site releases of any chemical, which could have had a impact to the public or en

vironment, in the last 5 years at the APG WTP and WWTP or the CFF as addressed by this RMP.

Emergency Response Program:

The APG Directorate of Safety, Health and Environment's Fire and Emergency Services Division (APG DSHE-FESD) is a comprehensive community and emergency service system.  In addition, DSHE-FESD is a member of the local community response network with mutual aid agreements in place to assist or be assisted by other fire departments, including the Harford County Hazardous Material Emergency Response Unit.  Emergency response personnel participate in addressing major regulations (such as the RMP) with other directorates/divisions that require emergency service planning.  Policy for the DSHE-FESD is defined by Army Regulation (AR) 420-90 which adopts the National Fire Protection Association codes for operation.

Planned changes:

Over the past several years, a number of accidental release prevention steps have been taken to improve the safety and reliability of the chlorine systems.  The chlorine distribution systems were converted to vacuum systems with controls that will stop the flow of chlorine in the event of a pipe break or similar equipment failure.  Additionally, the amount of on-site chlorine was reduced substantially.  A variety of physical security measures are in place at all facilities, to include patrols by armed security forces to prevent unauthorized access.  APG is committed to maintaining the effectiveness of the RMP, and no significant changes to the system are currently planned. The ammonia refrigeration system at the climatic firing facility is a new installation constructed and installed to the latest engineering design and safety standards. Additional safety valves have been installed in the system to substantially reduce the quantity of any release. In addition air monitoring has been installed in all buildings serviced by the refrigeration system to provide an early warning system for personnel in and around the facility and sy
stem equipment shutdown. No changes to the system are currently planned.
